itemBody.teacherInstructions:
TEACHER READS:
Read the question to yourself and select the best answer(s).

div.strong: This question has two parts. First, answer part A. Then, answer part B.
This section of the text is an extended example of personification, in which the sea is given humanlike qualities.

tr.td: Digging on the beach had been a favorite pastime for all the years he'd been living at the cottage, for as far back as he could remember. His grandmother told him it was childish. He didn't care. It comforted him. The sea always gave him something from its depths. It wouldn't fail him today.

div.strong: Which of the following is the most likely reason the author chose to personify the sea in this text, given the text's emotional overtones?

simpleChoice.p: The sea is frightening in earlier parts of the story, so the author wanted to change that perception toward the end and make it more humanlike.
The sea is important to the story. The story's theme of embracing change would be missed completely in any other setting. The sea is personified to add importance to it.
The sea is familiar and comforting to Francisco as he faces an unavoidable, unwanted change in his life. It is like a friend to him, so the personification is appropriate.

The sea is personified so that the other characters in the story, such as Francisco's grandmother and the developers, could form a greater appreciation for it. By the end, they see the sea as a friend, just as Francisco does.

rationale.p: Student(s) may have seen this as a rational answer, given that the story had emotional overtones that dealt with fear.

Student(s) may have agreed with the idea that the sea was important to the story and believed that the setting was essential. Student(s) may not have realized that the setting was not integral and the theme could have been conveyed using a different setting.
Student(s) may have wanted the other characters to respect the sea the way that Francisco did, but the story did not explicitly say so.

div.strong: Select the two pieces of evidence that support the answer to part A.

simpleChoice.p: Francisco's grandmother urges him to stop being sentimental and "go with the flow" of things.
Francisco tries not to see the "For Sale" sign in his yard.
Francisco sees the developers as greedy monsters that are going to destroy the "unsoiled beaches" that mean so much to him.
Francisco eavesdrops on his parents' conversations about moving.
Francisco longs to have an attitude more like his mother's attitude.
Francisco spends an afternoon at the seaside, finds a conch shell, and decides to take it with him to remember the sea and all his wonderful memories of it.

rationale.p: Student(s) may have chosen this answer in relation to answer option D from part A. Student(s) may have believed that the grandmother started the story out with no respect for Francisco's love of the sea, but later came to understand him.
Student(s) may have seen this answer as relating to Francisco's reluctance to change, but student(s) may not have read carefully enough to see that this answer did not relate to the ocean.

Student(s) may have assumed that this meant that Francisco was hoping that they were starting to change their minds and be more supportive of his attachment to the ocean, which would relate to answer option D from part A.
Student(s) may have thought that Francisco wanted to have a more mature attitude about leaving.
